3) What are the advantages of using a classless routing protocol?
Allows the use of VLSM and CIDR within the routing domain.

4) How does a classful routing protocol determine the subnet mask of a routing update?

If the network address in the routing update is on the same major classful network as the receiving interface, the classful routing protocol will use the same mask as the interface. Otherwise, it will use the default classful mask.

5) Why did the IETF introduce classless IP addressing, CIDR?

The routing tables on Internet routers were experiencing very high growth. There needed to be a way to summarize the routes in the routing table. Because classful addressing only provided for /8, /16, or /24 masks, the IPv4 address space was becoming depleted.

8) The 172.16.0.0/16 network is subnetted using a /24 subnet mask. What could we do if we needed to divide the 172.16.10.0/24 subnet into three equally sized subnets with the maximum number of hosts per subnet?
172.16.10.0/24 could be subnetted using the /26 subnet mask.
This would give us four subnets with the maximum number of hosts. We cannot do three subnets, the next lower number of subnets would be two.

10) What is supernetting? What is required to propagate a supernet route?

Supernetting refers to the ability to summarize networks less than the classful default mask. Classless routing protocols are required to propagate a supernet route because the subnet mask must be included with the summarized network address.
